seberg commented on pull request #8834:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8834#issuecomment-739976600


   @jorisvandenbossche 1.20 is a big release.  Early next year is my best guess, but I am not certain... Depends a bit how things go, if it turns out we only need a single RC it could be faster (but we were not holding our breath considering the size).

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #8834:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8834#issuecomment-740068880


   @seberg we are normally planning to do a next major release in January as well. We could try to do an RC first week of January after the holidays, and then a release by mid January could be realistic. So if there would not be much difference in timing, that would possibly avoid the need to do a shorter-term bugfix release on the pyarrow side.

seberg commented on pull request #8834:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8834#issuecomment-740073204


   Thanks, I will bring it up in our Wednesday meeting.  I am a bit surprised if this is a serious annoyance, but will am happy to trust you guys on it.  I definitely can't think of another way to mitigate any end-user annoyance, though. (And even if, I don't think it is worth potentially days of work compared to delaying a release for a few weeks.)

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #8834:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8834#issuecomment-740125082


   It's definitely a serious annoyance *in the time period between numpy releasing and pyarrow releasing with this fix* (because a plain `pip install pyarrow` will be broken in that period). But once there is a fixed pyarrow, I agree it will probably be OK (then it's only a problem for people upgrading numpy without upgrading pyarrow). 
   
   Ideally we would have a quick bugfix release, so numpy doesn't need to feel hindered by the pyarrow-numpy compatibility issue in deciding when to do your final release. Reality is though that our release process is unfortunately quite heavy-weight, so the question about timing has to be seen in that light.


----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

seberg commented on pull request #8834:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8834#issuecomment-748282652


   Out of curiosity, do you already have a time frame when a (bugfix or major) release of `pyarrow` will happen next?  I discussed this on the NumPy community call and nobody minded delaying the NumPy release for a bit. So I think we are fine with that, there is at least one more NumPy RC coming anyway soon.
   
   It would be nice to not delay more than a few weeks though (which I guess would make it "some time in January")?

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #8834:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8834#issuecomment-755386010


   The original target was end of this week. We have some problems with the wheel building and some other CI builds, at the moment, though (eg Python 3.9 wheel building), that needs to be sorted out before being able to release. So more realistically it will be next week for an RC, and then another week for the final release. 


----------------------------------------------------------------

users@infra.apache.org

seberg commented on pull request #8834:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8834#issuecomment-755697447


   We talked about this again, and unfortunately the best we can do is to say that we will release NumPy 1.20 by the end of the month.  Assuming your release process goes smoothly, that should work out. Otherwise, I guess there will be a short gap where a `pip install ...` could pull in a newer NumPy (if it is an upgrade or a fresh install) and cause issues.

Vyacheslav-Smirnov commented on pull request #8834:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8834#issuecomment-802905630


   Hi,
   
   Can this issue be also fixed for pyarrow 2.0.0?
   
   We use this package for Intel sdc and cannot migrate to pyarrow 3.0.0 version right now. Currently this is blocking us.
   
   Simpler reproducer is:
   
   python -m pip install pyarrow==2.0.0 numpy
   python
   >>> import pyarrow
   >>> pyarrow.from_numpy_dtype(int)
   Traceback (most recent call last):
     File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
     File "pyarrow/types.pxi", line 2544, in pyarrow.lib.from_numpy_dtype
     File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 107, in pyarrow.lib.check_status
   pyarrow.lib.ArrowTypeError: Did not pass numpy.dtype object


--

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.

fields.description: This is faulty in old versions and this will lead to a lot of issues with the upcoming numpy 1.20 release.
fields.summary: [Python] Avoid usage of NumPy's PyArray_DescrCheck macro

comments.body:
Hi [~uwe] ,

Can this issue be also fixed for pyarrow 2.0.0?

We use this package for Intel sdc and cannot migrate to pyarrow 3.0.0 version right now. Currently this is blocking us.

Simpler reproducer is:
{code:java}
python -m pip install pyarrow==2.0.0 numpy
python
>>> import pyarrow
>>> pyarrow.from_numpy_dtype(int)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "pyarrow/types.pxi", line 2544, in pyarrow.lib.from_numpy_dtype
  File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 107, in pyarrow.lib.check_status
pyarrow.lib.ArrowTypeError: Did not pass numpy.dtype object{code}
